texts.shortText:
Colony consists of a thin, flat, pale-pinkish or yellow sheet attached to the undersides of rocks, especially in intertidal pools.

The individual zooecia are more or less rectangular with a granular surface. The large semicircular aperture has a thickened margin and a thin transparent lid. Defensive individuals (avicularia) and rare and similar to, but slightly larger than, feeding individuals and have an inverted V-shape structure across the aperture.
Individual zooecia about 1 mm long, colonies typically 5-10 cm across.

Global: Virtually cosmopolitan in warmer seas.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Durban.
Common on the undersides of boulders in the intertidal and shallow subtidal to a depth of about 20 m. Colonies more or less circular, but zooids not arranged in rows. No other details available.

All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.

Hermaphrodite. Existing colonies expand by budding new zooecia around the margins. Also undertake sexual reproduction, and related species brood the eggs internally, but species -specific details not available.
The pale colour and large semicircular apertures distinguish this from the Rust-red bryozoan Watersipora subtorquata, which often also occurs as flat, round colonies under the same boulders.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 25).
